docs.lead_paragraph: Continuing the conversation about why health care in America is so expensive, Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, explains his pessimism about the Democrats' legislation emerging from Washington.

headline.main: Senator Enzi Says Bill Will Raise Costs

docs.abstract: Joining the Prescriptions blog's conversation on health care costs, Senator Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming, the senior Republican on the health committee, says he believes costs will rise.
docs.snippet: Joining the Prescriptions blog's conversation on health care costs, Senator Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming, the senior Republican on the health committee, says he believes costs will rise.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama told a black church in the nation's capital today that the promise inherent in his election as the nation's first African-American president has yet to be fully realized, acknowledging that partisan Washington politics continued to play a big role in governance.
docs.abstract: President Obama, in a rare speaking appearance at a church, told a black congregation that his promises hadn't been fully realized because of Washington-style partisan politics.
docs.snippet: President Obama, in a rare speaking appearance at a church, told a black congregation that his promises hadn't been fully realized because of Washington-style partisan politics.

docs.lead_paragraph: The tea party movement is being exploited, not just by marketers, lobbyists and corporate interests, but by Republican Party leaders.
docs.snippet: The tea party movement is being exploited, not just by marketers, lobbyists and corporate interests, but by Republican Party leaders.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Senate stand-in for Edward M. Kennedy, waits for the outcome of an election, he has helped to keep the health care bill moving.

headline.seo: Kirk Has a Whirlwind Senate Term, And Becomes 60th Vote
headline.main: A Truncated Term for the Democrats’ 60th Vote
headline.print_headline: A Truncated Term for the Democrats’ 60th Vote

docs.snippet: As Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Senate stand-in for Edward M. Kennedy, waits for the outcome of an election, he has helped to keep the health care bill moving.

headline.main: Letters in Response to the 1.3.10 Issue

docs.lead_paragraph: Is it alright to lie about smoking pot on an application for health insurance?
docs.snippet: Is it alright to lie about smoking pot on an application for health insurance?

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of well-off men are injecting a hormone to forestall aging. Does it work — or is it enough that they simply think it does?
docs.snippet: A growing number of well-off men are injecting a hormone to forestall aging. Does it work — or is it enough that they simply think it does?

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital. Their greatest hope is to defeat the bill outright, rebuffing President Obama on his signature domestic issue and weakening the Democrats heading into the midterm elections. Republicans now think they can persuade some conservative and moderate Democrats in the House to vote against the final bill, which initially passed the House by just five votes.

headline.main: G.O.P. Sees Political Gain in Health Care
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Republicans hope to defeat health care overhaul and deliver rebuff to Pres Obama on his signature domestic issue ahead of midterm elections; conservative Club for Growth has already put in place campaign to repeal bill if it passes; special Senate election in Massachusetts could indicate how potent health care issue will be in fall; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital.      Their greatest hope is to defeat the bill outright, rebuffing President Obama on his signature domestic...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital.

headline.main: G.O.P. Sees Political Gain in Health Care

docs.abstract: Republicans now think they can persuade some conservative and moderate Democrats in the House to vote against the final bill, and see the political tide as turning their way.
docs.snippet: Republicans now think they can persuade some conservative and moderate Democrats in the House to vote against the final bill, and see the political tide as turning their way.

docs.lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Mass. -- The candidates for the open United States Senate seat in Massachusetts are hopscotching the state via bus Saturday as the tight race to fill the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy's seat heads into its final days.

headline.main: Senate Candidates Storm the Bay State by Bus

docs.abstract: Both the Republican and Democratic candidate shited into get-out-the-vote drives before the special election on Tuesday.
docs.snippet: Both the Republican and Democratic candidate shited into get-out-the-vote drives before the special election on Tuesday.
